title: Building AI Agents and the Future of Software with Bret Taylor
description: Bret Taylor, co-founder and CEO of Sierra, former Salesforce co-CEO, former Facebook CTO, and OpenAI board chairman, discusses AI agents, product development strategy, engineering leadership, and lessons from building products across Google, Facebook, Salesforce, and his own companies.
summary: Bret Taylor covers the critical importance of agents as the future app paradigm, outcomes-based pricing in AI, how to think about building products beyond features and functionality, the importance of intellectual honesty about root causes of product failures, and how coding will transform from writing code to operating code-generating machines with proper systems thinking.

key_themes.theme: Agents as the New App Paradigm
key_themes.description: AI agents will replace traditional software as service offerings, fundamentally transforming how products achieve business outcomes and how companies price software
Moving from usage-based to outcomes-based pricing aligns vendor incentives with customer success and drives true productivity gains
The most important leadership heuristic is asking 'what is the most impactful thing I can do today' rather than defaulting to your comfort zone

key_themes.theme: Intellectual Honesty in Root Cause Analysis
key_themes.description: Understanding the real reasons for product failures and customer resistance requires honest investigation beyond surface-level customer feedback
Great product design is about systems that work with messy real-world input, not just beautiful mockups or feature lists
Future software development will shift from typing code to operating AI systems that generate code, requiring new programming languages optimized for verification and safety
Different product categories require different go-to-market motions - developer-led, product-led growth, or direct sales - based on buyer-user relationship

key_insights.quote: What is the most impactful thing I could do today?
key_insights.context: Bret describes the mindset that has contributed to his success across different roles and career levels
key_insights.insight: The single most important leadership heuristic is to constantly ask what will have the highest impact, rather than defaulting to your preferred activities or comfort zone

key_insights.quote: The whole market is going to go towards agents. I think the whole market is going to go towards outcomes-based pricing. It's just so obviously the correct way to build and sell software.
key_insights.context: Bret's opening statement about how the AI software market will evolve and consolidate
key_insights.insight: Agents and outcomes-based pricing represent a fundamental shift in the software industry, similar to the move from on-premise to cloud

key_insights.quote: It's so hard to sell productivity software, which I learned the hard way.
key_insights.context: Bret reflects on the challenge of selling traditional productivity improvements vs. autonomous agents
key_insights.insight: Traditional productivity software is hard to value because improvements are unattributable; agents solve this by delivering measurable, autonomous outcomes

key_insights.quote: I was trying to conform the job to the things I thought I liked to do. So, I was spending a lot of my time on some product and technology things that I was passionate about, thinking I'm the boss. I should focus on what I want to focus on instead of thinking about, okay, I'm running the mobile and platform teams at Facebook. What's the most important thing to do today to make our mobile and developer platform successful?
key_insights.context: Bret recounts Sheryl Sandberg's feedback that changed his approach to leadership at Facebook
key_insights.insight: The biggest mistake leaders make is optimizing for activities they enjoy rather than focusing on what the organization actually needs, which requires letting go of ego

key_insights.quote: I think it's really hard. One of the dangers for founders and product managers, but I think particularly for founders is incorrect storytelling. People don't like my product because of X. And if you tell that to yourself and you tell it to your team, all of a sudden, it goes from being an intuition to being a fact.
key_insights.context: Bret explains why understanding real reasons for customer problems is critical
key_insights.insight: Founders must avoid creating false narratives about why products fail; incorrect root cause analysis leads to solving the wrong problems and company failure

key_insights.quote: I think one is, it does come down to good judgment, I think. I don't know how to teach that. I'm a huge believer in good judgment. It's one of the things I hire for.
key_insights.context: Bret discusses how to evaluate which advisors to listen to and how to develop judgment
key_insights.insight: The most critical leadership skill is judgment - knowing whose advice to trust and why; this comes from self-reflection and holding yourself accountable for decisions

key_insights.quote: I think that computer science is more than coding. If you understand things like Big O notation or complexity theory or study algorithms... There's a lot more to coding than writing the code. The act of creating software is going to transform from typing into a terminal to operating a code-generating machine.
key_insights.context: Bret discusses whether learning to code is still valuable in an AI-driven future
key_insights.insight: Understanding systems thinking, complexity, and algorithmic efficiency remains critical even as AI generates code; the skill is operating the code-generating machine, not typing

key_insights.quote: At Facebook, we spent a lot of time designing the newsfeed and if you ever had a really, really good designer and they showed you a Photoshop mock-up of the newsfeed, it was just all as beautiful... And then you'd implement that design and you'd look at your own newsfeed and it looked like shit because it turns out not everyone's photos were made by a professional photographer.
key_insights.context: Bret explains why designing for systems with real-world messy data is fundamentally different from designing mockups
key_insights.insight: Product design must account for real-world data and edge cases, not just the happy path; designers must work with messy actual data to create systems that work at scale

key_insights.quote: I think a lot of companies should leverage direct sales more than they do. And even though because of the sometimes justified reputation of the quality of products of some of these direct sales companies, it had gotten a bad name. And I think I'm thankful to see it coming back in a lot of the AI market.
key_insights.context: Bret discusses why direct sales is the right go-to-market motion for many AI products
key_insights.insight: Founders should choose go-to-market based on buyer-user relationship and evaluation requirements, not just trend; direct sales is underrated and critical for products where buyer â‰  user

key_insights.quote: We spent a lot of time saying, what if we inverted the hierarchy here and made the map the canvas? We ended up finding Lars and Jens Rasmussen who had been working on this Windows mapping product and we got them into the company and started exploring this space.
key_insights.context: Bret describes the pivot that transformed Google Local into Google Maps - the 'V2' after the initial failure
key_insights.insight: When a product fails, look for a fundamental insight that inverts existing assumptions; Google Maps succeeded by making maps the primary interface rather than search results

key_insights.quote: I think first is, I think as you have these new technologies, rather than literally digitizing what came before, if you can create an entirely new experience, it answers the question for a new customer, why should I give this the time of day?
key_insights.context: Bret reflects on the key lesson from Google Maps - why disruptive products win
key_insights.insight: Don't digitize existing solutions; create entirely new experiences that answer why customers should care, not just why your version is better than competitors

key_insights.quote: At Sierra, we say, 'Hey, if the AI agent solves the customer's problem, they're happy with it and you didn't have to pick up the phone,' there's a pre-negotiated rate for that and we call it resolution based... what's really neat about it is it really just aligns... I think every technology company aspires to be a partner, not a vendor.
key_insights.context: Bret explains how Sierra's outcomes-based pricing model works and why it creates true partnership
key_insights.insight: Outcomes-based pricing aligns incentives perfectly - vendor success depends on customer success, transforming the relationship from vendor to partner

key_insights.quote: I do think operating a code-generating machine requires systems thinking... your job as the operator of that code-generating machine is to make a product or to solve a problem and you really need to have great systems thinking... systems thinking is always the hardest part of creating products.
key_insights.context: Bret discusses what skills remain critical as AI generates code
key_insights.insight: Systems thinking will become MORE important as code generation becomes commoditized; the hard part is always defining what system solves the business problem

key_insights.quote: If an AI is generating this code, by definition, if you have to read every line that is going to be the limiting factor for producing the code... So, the question is how do you enable humans to have as much leverage as possible?
key_insights.context: Bret discusses why new programming languages are needed to support AI code generation
key_insights.insight: Future programming systems should emphasize verifiability and safety over ergonomics; languages like Rust that offer compile-time guarantees become more valuable with AI code generation

key_insights.quote: I think there's a lot of insights in programming languages that could serve this... it's like the guy in the matrix with the green letters coming down, how can I make something so I as a operator of the code generating machine can produce incredibly complex scale software, incredibly quickly and know that it works?
key_insights.context: Bret envisions the future of software development as operating AI systems with proper safeguards
key_insights.insight: The future programming system should enable humans to create complex systems with confidence through better verification, testing, and supervision mechanisms - this is a design opportunity

frameworks_mentioned: Jobs to be Done (mentioned as influential but from Competing Against Luck by Clayton Christensen)
Root cause analysis for product failures
